Background.text:
US and Canada with more than 13 million trauma patients per year at risk for C-spine injury
Most blunt trauma patients will be placed in a cervical collar by EMS to protect the C-spine
C-spine can be clinically cleared by trained personnel

NEXUS_Cervical_Spine_Rule.text:
Radiography is not necessary if the patient satisfies
ALL
of the following low risk criteria:
No midline cervical tenderness
No focal neuro deficits
Normal alertness
No intoxication
No painful distracting injury
C-spine imaging should be considered unless the patient meets all of the above low risk criteria
[1]
[2]

No_High_Risk_Factors.text:
Age >65
Dangerous mechanism (fall>3ft/5 stairs, high speed MVC (>60mph)/rollover/ejection, bicycle crash, RV, axial load injury)
Parasthesias in extremities

ANY_Low_Risk_Factor.text:
Simple rear end MVC
Delayed onset of pain
Sitting position in ED
Ambulatory at any time
Absence of midline C-spine tenderness

ROM.text:
Rotates neck 45 degrees to left and right
C-spine can be cleared clinically if above criteria met
[3]
[4]

Canadian_rule_vs._Nexus.text:
A single trial showed Canadian rule would pick up 312 or 313 clinically important cases, while NEXUS would miss 1 one in 10 cases
[5]

Criteria_Met.text: If CCSR or NEXUS criteria is met, patient can be cleared clinically

Criteria_Not_Met.text:
If unable to be cleared by CCSR or NEXUS then imaging is indicated with CT C-spine is indicated
CT recommended over xray
For significant injury CT has a sensitivity of 100% while xray has a sensitivity 36%

Altered_Patient.text:
EAST (Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma) performed systematic review in 2015
[10]
Review included 1800 obtunded patients generally defined as GCS<13 with negative CT c-spine using <3mm axial cuts
Of 1800 patients, 176 patients with abnormal MRI
None (or 0/176) had unstable C-spine injury
EAST guideline notes:
We conditionally recommend cervical collar removal after a negative high-quality C-spine CT scan result alone
[11]
C-spine clearance with CT was highly accurate and reliable for identifying clinically significant spine injuries, and had a 100% NPV for identifying unstable injuries.
[12]
10,191 patient multicenter prospective study
Supplement to EAST recommendations
99.9% NPV for clinically significant C-spine injuries
The practice of continuing spine precautions due to concerns about intoxication despite a negative CT scan only result in significantly prolonged immobilization and c-collar wear, with no benefit in identifying additional injuries
Prolonged C-spine immobilization is still at times selectively used in both sober or intoxicated patients based on evaluation, individual threshold and practice
